revised_title: Exploring Negative After-Images and Retinal Excitation
tldr: The author, Shelford Bidwell, conducted experiments using a rotating disk to study negative after-images following brief retinal excitation. He discovered that when a person looks at a colored object, their retina can create a negative after-image of complementary colors, which can be seen when viewing the object through the rotating disk. This phenomenon can help explain the greenish-blue borders that appear around bright objects and the abnormal whiteness of black objects.
